titleStmt.title: A narrative of the late Parliament, (so called) their election and appearing, the seclusion of a great part of them. The sitting of the rest. With an account of the places of profit, sallaries, and advantages which they hold and receive, under the present power. With some queries thereupon: and upon the most materiall acts and proceedings passed by them. All, humbly proposod [sic] to consideration; and published for information of the people. By a friend to the Common-Wealth, and to its dear bought rights and freedome.
titleStmt.author: Friend to the Common-Wealth, and to its dear bought rights and freedome.

With an account of the places of profit, sallaries, and advantages which they hold and receive, under the present power. projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

Full documentation of the original data capture process is available from the Text Creation Partnership web site. All versions of the texts are now archived and freely available for download. See the TCP Download FAQ for detailed information. The TEI P5 versions are also freely available from the TCP Github repository.

keywords.term: England and Wales. -- Parliament -- Early works to 1800.
Great Britain -- Politics and government -- 1649-1660 -- Early works to 1800.

2014-03 Amanda FlynnText and markup reviewed and edited

div.p:
A NARRATIVE of the late Parliament, (so called)
Their Election and Appearing,
The Seclusion of a great part of them.
The Sitting of the rest.
With an Account of the Places of Profit, Sallaries, and Advantages which they Hold and Receive, under the Present Power.
With some Queries thereupon: And upon the most materiall Acts and Proceedings Passed by them.
ALL, Humbly Proposod to Consideration; and Published for Information of the People. By a Friend to the COMMON-WEALTH, and to its Dear bought Rights and Freedome.
Anno 1657.

div.head: A Narrative of the late Parliament (so called) their Election and Appearing; The Seclusion of a great Part of them; The Sitting of the rest: With an account of the Places of Profit, Sallaries, and Advantages which they Hold and Receive under the Present Power, &c.
div.p:
IT is not unknown unto all Intelligent and Observing People, what great stickling and underhand dealing was put in practise by the Court Party, in driving on interests and Designes, about Choosing this last pretended Parliament: In improving the Major Generals to that purpose (who were not wanting in the matter) As also by writing of Letters to the Sheriffs, who were (some of them) very officious in that service; whereby severall worthy Patriots had very foule and unequall termes offered them, not being suffered to be put in Nomination; justifying their proceedings to be no other than according to Order they had so to doe; Middlesex, Chesh-shire, Berks-shire, and the City of Canterbury, may serve for instances instead of others: Neither were the Clergy behinde in endeavours for the Advancement of their own Interest; as appeared by meetings held in very many Counties, to agree, and make Choise before hand among themselves, and then promote their Choise against the Election Day; And upon the day appearing like so many Captains, or Leaders, cryed up the parties they had chosen before to serve their Interest. But what cause the People have to rejoyce, and give them thanks for this Service, doth already in part appear; and further may, when they shall feel the burthens of Excise and Customs, with the many Fetters and Snares attending the same; As also a Tax backward to be paid
over again. And another for three years together, never the like in England before: Together with a new Project to raise mony out of all such Houses, for ten Miles distance without the Walls of the City af London, that from thirty seven years past, to the 29. of September last, have been built upon new foundations; with other Acts serving designes, but not one for the ease of the people, or the punishment of those who have wronged and abused them. By which Acts these Gentlemen, and those that chose them, make themselves Accessary too, and as much as in them lies, guilty of all this hard bondage, that now is, or may further come upon us.

The Gentlemen ehosen to sit in this Assembly, accordingly made their Appearance, and gave attendance at Westminster in Order to that service, where a great number of them finde themselves secluded the House, and not suffered to enter in to do their duty, who having waited a day, or two without success, many of them made an Address to their fellow members sitting in the House, for their admittance: Some of the names of those Gentlemen so kept out of the House here followeth.
Sr. Arthur Hasserigg
Thomas Scott
Herbert Morley
John Bulkley
John Birch
Collonel Fenwick
Anthony Erby
Thomas Lister
Thomas Birch
Thomas Sanders
Henry Darley
John VVeaver
Alexander Popham
Francis Thorp
Anth. Ashley Cooper
John Southby
Richard Greenvil
Thomas Adams
Richard Brown
Richard Darley
Thomas St. Nicholas
VVilliam James
John Boyse
Charls Hill
John Jones
VViliam VVolley
Richard Radcliff
VVilliam Savill
Theo. Biddulph
Henry Mildmay
Harb. Grimston
VVilliam VVelby
Charles Hussey
Edmond Harvey
John Sicklemore
William Doyly
Ralph Hare
John Hubbard
Olive Raymond
Jeremiah Bentley
Phillip Woodhouse
John Buxton
VVilliam Bloyse
VVilliam Gibbs
Thomas Southerton
Sr. Thomas Bows
Edward Harlow
John Hanson
Clement Throgmorton
Henry North
Sir Iohn VVittrong
George Courthop
Samuel Gost
John Buckland
Robert Long
Iohn Northcot
Iohn Young
Iohn Doddrige
Henry Hungerford
Edward Yooker
VVilliam Morrice
Iohn Haile
Edward Tukner
Challen Chute
Daniel Shatterden
Sir Thomas Styles
Richard Beale
VVall. Moyle
VVall. Vincent
Iohn Gell
Henry Arthington
Henry Tempest
Iames Clavering
Iohn Stanhop
Pen: VVhaly
Abell Burker
Samuell More
Thomas Minors
Samuell Iones
Edward Hooper
Richard VVinneve
Iohn Fagg
Thomas Rivers
Henry Peckham
Charles Lloyd
Iohn Thurbone
VVilliam Flisher
Iohn Gore
Row. Litton.
The Answer of the Gentlemen in the House, to the forementioned Address, was to this effect, viz. That those Gentlemen must addresse themselves to the Councell.

Upon the unsatisfactorinesse and injustice of which Answer these Gentlemen, rather than they would yeeld to so great a Violation of Parliamentary Power, Resolved to depart to their own Countries again, which accordingly they did.

Upon this Breach made in the House, and giving up the Rights and Interest of the English Nation in Parliament, to be judged without doores, by an inferiour power; divers Gentlemen then sitting in the House, who being endued with Principles of Justice, and Righteousnesse, and love to the Nations freedome, immediately withdrew; and others would not enter into the House at all, but departed to their severall habitations.

div.head: Ʋpon all which, it is Proposed and Queried.
div.p: First, Whether since the Conquest there was ever such a blow given (by a People owning themselves a Parliament) to the Interest and freedome of the English Nation, as the suffering to be secluded from them (by an inferiour Power) so great a number of Members chosen by the People to sit, as their Representors in Parliament, without any Cause shewn for such a proceeding.

2. How this upstart Protector and his Councel, of a little more than three years standing, should come to be impowred to do those things, which a King and his Councel of more than four hundred years descent could not, nor durst not doe. And whether the late, together with the former Force put upon the House, by excluding fo many of their Members be not a Crime twentyfold beyond that of the late Kings, in going about to seclude the Five Members, so highly disrescented in that day by the People, and afterwards attended with so great fewd and bloodshed?

3. Whether till this unworthy Generation, there ever were such a Company of false-hearted, low-spirited, mercenary Englishmen Sitting in that House before, that would at once so easily give up the Right, Interest, and Freedome of this Nation, in suffering their Fellow-Members to be rent from them, and judged without doores; As if there were a just Power at present upon Earth, higher, and greater than the good Peoples Representors in Parliament: Which by all well affected people in the Army and elsewhere was so generally acknowledged the Supream Authority?

Fourthly, Whether these Persons in thus doing, as also in Confirming (as it were) this Usurpation by a Law, in settling the Government in a single Person and his Councell, with a House of Lords as it was before; giving him a Negative Voice, and the power of disposing the Malitia and Navy, things formerly so muchSee in a representation of the Army, and large Petition, in Book called Looking glass, p. 5, 11, 12, 13. And in Alb. Remonst. p 25, 26. A Letter p. 40. In Act of Parliam. after beheading of the King. p. 44. of the same Book. and in Declaration 19. July 1650. p. 47. and Declaration 1. August following p. 49, 50. and in Declaration after the old Parliament was disolved, see page 54. of the same Book, all procured in that day by the now Protector, so called, and the then honest part of the Army. complained off, and opposed, as the effects of Tyranny and Usurpation in the late King; together with many other things done by them, tending to oppresse and Enslave the People; have not as much as in them lies pulled upon themselves and the three Nations, the guilt of all the Blood of the late Wars, acknowledged by the Army and others, to be shed in removing the foresaid Evils; as likewise to make void and fruitlesse the vast summs of money, and Treasure expended upon that account?

5. Whether the aforesaid Gentlemen are not therefore to be esteemed by all true hearted English men, asSee Looking glass p. 47. in Declaration July 19. 1650. the Army confesse so much themselves. betrayers off, and Traytors to the Cause of God, and their Countreys Liberties, and a company of Sallary men; Sonnes, Servants, Kinsmen and Lawyers, &c. purposely pact to enthrone their Protectors single Interest, rather than a Parliament of the Common wealth of England, Lawfully called and constituted to carry on the good old Cause, viz. The promoting of Reformation, and vindication of the peoples Liberties.

6. Whether some of those Gentlemen who were secluded, with other that were injuriously hindered from being chosen, have not been more faithfull to the Cause formerly contended for; And better Patriots to their Countrey, And such who less deserve why they should be rejected, than such as Mr. Glyn, Mr. Nicholls, (two of the eleven Members, who endeavouring to settle the same things upon the King, they have now pretended to doe upon their Protector, were counted false to God and the people) Sr, Charlss Ousley and Commissioner Fines.

7. And whether Mr. Thomas St. Nicholas, Collonel Dixwell, &c. Were not as capable, and every way more likely to Councel and advise for the good of their Countrey, As the Sons of Major General Desbrow, of Mr. Lawrence President of the Council, and of Sr Hardress Waller, as yet both in years and experience Children.

Eightly, Doth not this picking a lukewarm Neuter, from one place, a Cavaleere from another, and young youths of no Principles from another: And packing them with his Kindred, Sons, Servants, and Sallary men, and a sort of Conquered Scotch men? A thing formerly so muchSee Lookinglass p. 22. in Remonstrance at Albons. feared and complained of in the late King? Now plainly declare that his pretence in Dissolving the Old Parliament; for not making provision in their Act for a New Representive toSee p. 58. of the same book, in his speech to the little Parliament. keep out Presbyters and Neuters was false; And that it was rather done as a farther step whereby he might ascend into this present greatness, then for the preservation of the Cause, which at that time was so highly pretended too?

Ninethly, Or is this practice in the least measure agreeing with that Spirit pretended unto in the choise of the little Parliament, or with that profession made by him in his Speech to them, viz. That they had not allowed themselves in the choise of one person, of whom they had not this good hope, there wasSee Looking glass p. 61. 63. and 59. in the speech he made to them in his own, and Officers Names. faith in Jesus Christ, and love to all the Saints. And that they judged it their duty to chuse none but godly men of principles, men knowing and fearing the Lord, who had made observations of his marveilous Dispensations; Such as he had formed for himself; because he expected not praises from others, And these the onely fit men to be entrusted with the Cause and no others: And therefore went in that extraordinary way, & not in the way of the Nation, because till the spirit was more powred forth, the people would not be in a capacity to choose such men, &c. Now whether the late picking and choosing (as is before exprest) a party of men of such a Spirit, and under such Qualifications, as this present Parliament (so called) is off, be not a notorious destroying of that profession and principle, then owned, and seemingly practised, Let all honest, and unbyast men judge.

div.head: Here follows the Truest and best Account that as yet can be gotten of the Names of those Gentlemen, who continued in the House, and have places of profit, Offices, Sallaries and advantages in the Common-wealth. Together with the Names of the Sons, Kinsmen, Servants, and others, who are under Engagements unto, and have dependance upon the Protector (so called) who being so well seasoned with the Salt of his Palace, according to Ezra 4.14. must needs be devoted to his Interest, wherein their own is wholly involved.

list.head: Of the Council.
list.item: Mr Lawrence as President 1000l. per Annum

Major General Lambert as one of the Council 1000l. per Annum: As Major General of the Army 365l. As Collonel of Horse 474l. 10s. Collonel of Foot 365l. and as is reported had the Generals pay 3640l. per Annum: as Major General of some Countreys 666l. 13s. 4d. in all 6 511l. 3s. 4d. These places he had, but whether he hath the Conscience to receive thus for them, or gives any away to those that act under him, is best known to himself; he is also a Lord of the Cinque Ports.

Lievetenant General Fleetwood as one of the Council, 1000l. per annum, as Lord Deputy of Ireland, 3640l, per annum, as Collonel of Horse in Ireland, 474l. 10s, collonel of Foot there 365l as collonel of Horse in England 474l, 10s. as Major General of some Counties 666l, 13s, 4d, in all 6620l, 13, 4d. Its said he remained Lievt. General of the Horse in England. It is supposed he hath all these places, but whether he receives all the pay or gives any to those that act under him, h mself best knowes. He Married the Protectors Daughter.

Major General Disbrow as one of the Council 1000l per annum, as General at Sea 109 5l. Collonel of Horse 474l, 10s. as Major General of the VVestern Countries 666l, 13s, 4d. in all 3236l, 3s, 4d. per annum. It is said he is one of the Cinque port Lords. He married the Protectors Sister, whereby he is doubly engaged to serve his Brothers Interest.
Collonel Mountague as one of the Council 1000l per annum, Commissioner of the Treasury 1000l. as General at Sea 1095l, in all 309 5l. per annum.
Collonel Sydenham as one of the Council 1000l. per annum, one of the Commissioners of the Treasury 1000l. in all 2000l. per annum, besides the Government of the Isle of Wight.
Collonel Fines as one of the Council 1000l per annum, Commissioner of the great Seal 1000l. as Keeper of the privy Seal, supposed worth 1000l, more, in all 3000l. per annum.
Sir Charles Ousley as one of the Council 1000l per annum.
Mr. Strickland as one of the Council 1000l. per annum, and is Captain of the gray coat foot guard at White hall.
Sir Gilbert Pickering as one of the Council 1000l. per annum, Chamberlain at Court, and Steward of Westminster.
Major General Skippon as one of the Council 1000l. per annum, as Major General of the Citty, it is supposed he hath 666l, 13s, 4d. according to his Brethren Major Generals of the Countries.
Mr. Rouse as one of the Council 1000l per annum, as Provost of Laton Colledg 500l. in all 1500l. per annum.

Collonel Phillip Jones as one of the Council 1000l. per annum, he either is or was his master Cromwell's Steward, or Overseer of his Lands in Wales, and is Custos Rotulorum of two or three Counties there.

Mr. John Thurlo Secretary of State and chief Postmaster of England, places of a vast income, he may justly be said to have a great hand in bringing all this abominable VVickednes, Slavery and Oppression that hath been for above these years to this very day upon the Nation.

div.head:
Here follows the names of those Lawyers that continued in the House, who have advantages from the State, who are placed in the van of the
Souldiers, as the more honourable persons, their General having lately laid aside, and delivered up his Sword to put on the Gown.

list.item: Sir Thomas Widdrington as Speaker of the House 35l. per week, which is 182 l per annum, as Commissioner of the Treasury 1000l, per ann. in all, 2829l per annum, and hath besides for every private Act 5l. and for every stranger that is Naturalised or made a free Denison; and hath gotten for that already as is supposed nere 1500l. He is Recorder of York, having these great engagements upon him he can do no other (if it be required) than put on the Kings old Robe, upon his Lord Protector.
Lord Whitlock as Commissioner of the Treasury 1000l. per annum; his son is a Captain in the Army, and lately made a Knight, he must needs serve the Court Interest.
Lord Lisle one of the Commissioners of the great Soal 1000l. per annum.
Mr. William Lenthal Speaker of the old Parliament formerly, as master of the Rowls supposed worth 2000l. per annum.

Mr. Prideaux as Atturney General to the State 5l. for every Patent, and 5l for every Pardon, and by the liberty of Pleading within Barre, together with 2000l▪ he gets by great Fees; it is supposed to amount to in all neer 6000l. per annum.

Mr. Glyn one of the eleven Members formerly impeached by the Army of treason, now Lord chief Iustice of England, for which he hath 1000l. per annum, besides other advantages, a man of Principles fitted for the Interest of Monarchy.
Mr. Ellis as Soliciter General to the State hath as is supposed neer 3000l. per annum.
Mr. Parker as one of the Barons of the Exechequer 1 00l per annum.
Baron Nicholas the same place, and sallary.
Baron Hall the same place and sallary
Mr. Lechmore Atturney of the Dutchy, his advantage thereby not well known.
Mr. Nathaniel Bacon as one of the Masters of Requests 500l. per annum.
Mr. Francis Bacon the like place and sallary.

Lislebone Long lately one of the Masters of Requests, and the better to carry on his Masters Interest, among the low spirited, Mayor, Aldermen and common Council in the Citty, is now made Recorder of London▪ supposed worth 2000l. per annum and is also a new Knight to the new Court.
Miles Fleetwood one of the Clarks of the privie seale supposed worth between 3. and 400l. per an.
Mr. Robert Shapcot one of the commissioners for executing that abominable oppressive wicked act for the new buildings his sallary as yet unknown,
Thomas Bamfeild Recorder of Exon.
Thomas Westlake Towne clarke.
Mr. Lister Recorder of Hull.
Guibbon Goddard Recorder of Lyn.
Lambert Godfery Recorder of Maidstone.
Collonel Mathews Recorder of Malden.

div.head:
The Names of the Officers belonging to the Armyes of England, Scotland and Ireland, and their Garisons and such as are of the Country
Troops, and the late created Major Generalls.

list.head: Of the Army in England.
list.item: Collonel Whaley, as Commissary General of the horse, 273 l , 15 s , per an, as Collonel of horse, 474 l , 105, besides other advantages in the Regiment; as one of the Major Generals of the Counties, 666 l , 13 s , 4 d in all 1414 l , 18 s , 4 l per annum.

Collonel Grosvenor as Quartermaster General 419 l , 10 s. per annum and its said hath Captain of Horse pay, and the better to carry it in the choise at Westminster; the souldiers were bid pull off their red-coats and put on others, and to give their Vote for him, which is contrary to Article 18th. of the old decayed Instrument of Government, which allows none that is not worth 200 l. to choose Parliament men.

George Downing as Scoutmaster General 365 l. per annum, one of the Tellers in the Exchequer, 500 l. in all 865 l, per annum, its said, he hath the Captains pay of a Troop of horse; formerly Scoutmaster against Cavaleers and Mosse troopers, but now against the Saints, and sends spyes amongst the Churches.
Mr Marieth as Judge Advocate of the Army, 273 l. 15 s. per annum.
Captain Blackwell as Treasurer of the Army 600l. per an.
Collonel Ingoldsby as Collonel of horse 474l. 10s. per an, beside other advantages in the Regiment he is Protectors (so called) kinsman, and will make no scruple to do what ever he will have him.
Collonel Hacker as Collonel of horse the same pay, and advantages in the Regiment.
Collonel Winthrop of horse the same,
Collonel Robert Lilburn as Collonel of horse, and 666l. 13s. 4d. as one of the Major Generals, is in all 1141l. 3s. 4d.
Collonel Berry as collonel of horse, and one of the Major Generals the like pay,
Major Packer, as collonel of horse, and Major General, the like advantage,

Collonel Goff, as collonel of horse, and Major General the like; This is he that with collonel White, brought the soldiers, and turned the honest party remaining behind in the little Parliament out of doores,
Collonel Bridges as collonel of horse and a Major General the same advantage with the others, this is he of whom its reported dealt treacherously with his collonel Okey to get his place.
Majoy Hains, as Major of Fleetwoods Regiment of horse, 358l. 18s 4d. and as a Major Generall 666d. 13s. 4d. in all, 102 5l. 1. 1s. 8d. per an.
Major Buller of horse, and as major generall the same advantage.
Major Wareing, if not Major of horse he is Captain of the County Troop, and a farmer of the Excise in the country
Captain Baines as Captain of horse, 273l, per an, beside other advantages in the Troop, as one of the committee of Preservation of the exercise and custome 300l, in all 573l, per an.
Captain Fox captain of horse and governor of Pendennis Castle he maryed Protectors (so called) Kinswoman.
Captain Scotten, Captain of horse 273l. per an, beside other advantages in the Troop.
Captain Lilburn of horse, the like advantage.
Major Jenkins (so called) captain of a Troope of horse, the like advantage

list.head: Officers belonging to the Regiments of horse in Ireland.
list.item: Collonel Reynolds, as Commissary general of horse, 273l. per an, as coll. of horse, 474l. 10s. in all 747l. 10s. per, an. And is now General of the English Army under the dispose of the Protectors Brother and confederate cardinal Mazarine in France and is one of the new made Knights.
Collonel Zenchy as collonel of horse, 474l. 10s. per an. beside other advantages, And lives much in Fleetwoods house.
Sr. Theophilous Jones, as Major of horse, 358l. 18s. 4d. per an. besides other advantages.
Major Morgan of Fleetwoods Regiment the same.
Major Owen, as Major of horse the same.
Major Redman, as Major of horse the like.
Collonel Abbot collonel of Dragoones.

list.head: Officers belonging to the Regiments of foot in England, that sat in the House.
list.item: Collonel Baxter, as captain of a foot company, 146l. per an. besides other advantages in the company as Major General of Middlesex, 666l. 13s 4d. as Lieutenant of the Tower. 250l. The benefit of ten Warders pay who had a lively hood by it, he having so procured that as they dye, or are otherwise laid aside, the 200l. per an, which paid them, comes in to his pocket, besides a fee, or fine imposed upon all persons, brought as prisoners into the Tower, according to their quality And hath the benefit of the wharfe, and letting of houses in the Tower and severall other advantages, which are oppressive, amounting to in all (as is conceived) about, 2000l, per an: He is one of the new made Knights, and one of the commissioners for suppressing the Printing presses as the Bishops Panders in the Kings days, one that makes men offenders, and casts them into prison for words, he hath drawn forth from them in examining against themselves: A Lyar, one that deals more injuriously with the Lords people, keeping many times their neerest relations and friends from coming to them; (witnesse that faithfull friend to the cause of God, and his People, Major general Overton amongst others) then Heathens Acts 24.23. and yet since this, is he taken in to be a member of Mr Griffiths church.

Collonel Pride as collonel of foot, 365l per annum, besides other advantages; and hath also great advantage by brewing for the State, one of the simple new made Knights, and his daughter married to the Protectors Nephew,

Collonel Clark as collonel of foot 365l per annum, as a commissioner of the Admiralty 500l per an, in all 865l. per ann. and one of the committe of the Army, he married Thurloes sister, and is deeply engaged to uphold the Court Interest.
Collonel Salmon as of foot and commissioner of the Admiralty 865l per an.
Liev. collonel Kelsey, as commissioner of the Admiralty 500l per annum, as one of the Major generals 666l. 13s. 4d. in all 1166l. 13s. 4d, besides the government of Dover castle,
Collonel Biscoe, as of foot 365l per annum, this is he who stood at the Parliament Doore with Collonel Mils to keep all the members out who had not Tickets

Collonel White of foot the like pay, beside other advantages in the Regiment as the other; this is he who with collonel
Goff brought souldiers and turned the members left behind in the little Parliament out of doores,

Captain Howard, formerly captain of the Lifeguard, as col. of foot 365l, per annum, and captain of a county troop 100l. in all 465l, per annum, besides the government of Berwick, Carlisle and Tinmouth, a printed book sayes he is a Major general.
Major Sanders of foot, and governour of Plimouth Fort, and Isleland.
Captain Wagstaff as Captain of foot, 146l besides the advantage of his company, and captain of a county Troop 100l, in all 246l, per annum.

list.head: Officers belonging to the Regiments of Foot in Scotland that sat in the House.
list.item: Collonel Fitz, as col. of foot 365l, per annum, and Governour of Innernesse.
Collonel Mitchel the like pay, besides other advantages in the Regiment.
Collonel Talbot col. of foot the like.

Collonel Cooper, as col. of two Regiments of foot, one in Scotland, the other in Ireland 720 l. per annum, besides other advantages in the Regiment, and the goverment of Carrickesergus, and a great part of the Country in the North of Ireland, its reported he both three or foure places.
Judge Advocate Whaly of the Army in Scotland 273 l. 15 s. per annum, beside other advantages, he is Commissary General Whales brother.

list.head: Officers belonging to the Regiments of foot in Ireland, who either did or might sit in the House; and such as are in civill employment there.
list.item: Sir Hardresse Waller, as Major General of the Army 365 l. per annum, as col. of foot 365. in all 730 l. per annum, besides other advantages.
Collonel Huson, col. of foot, and Governour of Dublin, with other advantages.
Collonel Fooke, col. of foot, and Governour of Droghedah.
Collonel Henry Ingoldsby, a col. of foot besides other advantages, and is the Protectors (so called) kinsman.
Collonel Sadler, col. of foot, besides other advantages.
Sr. Robert King, Commissary of the Musters, a place of good advantage, he is lately deceased.

list.head: These following Persons for Ireland, (but one) have the names of Officers but are none.
list.item: Collonel Bridges, Captain of a Foot company.
Lievt. coll. Newbrough.
Lievt. col. Berrisford.
Lievt. col. Treyle
Major Asten.
Captain Halfie.

div.p:
Persons not thought meet to be in Command, though they much desire it; and are of such poore principles, & so unfit to make Rulers off, as they would
not have been set with the dogs of the flock (as Job speaks in another case, Job 30.1.) If the Army and others who once pretended to be honest, had kept close to their former good and honest principles.

list.item: Collonel Jephson, a man of no better principles than the former, but for his good service in Voting for a King, is lately sent Embassador to Sweden.
Mr. Vincent Gookin, one of the letters of Land in Ireland, 300 l. per annum.
Mr. Ralph King, the like place and sallary.
Mr. Bice Recorder of Dublin.

list.head: The Names of those Collonels, Lievtenant Collonels, Majors, Captains, and Governours of Towns, that are not of the marching Army, which sat in the House.
list.item: Collonel Norton, a Regiment or some companies of Foot, and Governour of Portsmouth.
Collonel Rogers. Governour of Hereford, captain of a county troop, what companies of foot, and other advantages, is not certainly known.
Collonel Bingham Governor of Guernsie.
Collonel Coppleston, hath a county Regiment, made high Sheriff for three years together, supposed worth to him 3, or 400 l. per annum, one of the new made Knights, and a great Cavaleer formerly.
Collonel Cox, captain of a county Troop, for that 100 l. per annum.
Collonel Ireland, captain of a county Troop.
Collonel Iohn Gorges, captain of a county Troop.
Major Hawksworth, Governour of Warwick Castle, one or two companies of Foot, beside other advantages.
Major Bowreman, Deputy Governour of the Isle of Wight; he hath command of Sandown, and Weymouth Castles, one or two companies of foot, his other advantages not certainly known.
Captain Fiennes, hath a county troop.
William Braddon, the same command and pay.
Captain Crofts the like.
Captain VVhitegreave the like.
Captain Ludlow the like.
James Heely Lievtenant to that troop,

Captain Mason, Lievtenant to Hereford troop, and would get higher, if he could; a poore inconsiderable creature, That sayes, his lord must bestow some good place upon him, or else he can not serve him.

list.head: The Names of the Governours of Towns, Castles, and Commanders of the Malitia forces in Wales, and such as have Civil imployments who sat in the House.
list.item: Collonel Dawkins, Governour of Carmarthen. one of the Deputy Major Generals, captain of a Malitia troop.
Evan Lewis, captain of a county Troop.
Hugh Price of Guerny, captain of a Malitia troop, and Governour of Red castle.
John Price, Receiver General of South-VVales, and a great Treasurer formerly, now one of the Admiralty, or a commissioner of appeals.
Bennet Hoskins Deputy or puny Judge in Pembrooke, Carmarthen and Cardigan shires.
Griffith Bedward, hath a great place in the VVine Office at Westminster.
Collonel John Carter, by Judge Glyns Interest had lately 3000 l. Voted him by the House, for old Arrears, to be paid out of the Prize goods.
Collonel James Phillips, one of the committee of the Army, what other place not known at present.

div.head: The Names of such, who did or might sit in the House, that belong to the Admiralty and Navy.

list.item: General Blake, as General at Sea 1095 l. per annum, besides other advantages: lately deceased.
Mr. Hopkins one of the Commissioners of the Admiralty, 500 l. per annum: lately deceased.
Major Beak of Coventry, as Commissioner of the Admiralty 500 l, per annum.
Captain Hatsell, as Commissioner of the Navie at Plymouth 300 l. per annum.
Mr. Smith, as Commissioner of the Navie the like.
Collonel Rouse Vice Admiral of the North and South coast of Cornwall, a place of good value.
Charles George Cock, as one of the Judges of the Admiralty 500 l. per annum. And as a Commissioner of the Prerogative Court 300 l. in all 800 l per annum.
Major Audley, as an Officer of the Ordnance neer 300 l. per annum, Captain of a County Troop 100 l. per annum, and Deputy Major General to Kelsey.

div.head: The names of such who have Civill Employments who serve for Scotland.

list.item: Lord Broghill, as President of the Council there, 1000 l. per annum, besides other advantages, as Collonel of Horse in Ireland 474 l 10 s. in all 1474 l. 10 s. he was formerly not thought meet to be trusted with the government of a Town in Ireland, because looked upon as an old Protestant, and no thorough friend to the honest Interest, yet through the late defection is now received into this great Trust.
Collonel VVhetham, as one of the council in Scotland, its supposed 500 l. per annum.
Sir VVilliam Rhodes, as one of the council the like.
Mr. Disbrow Major General Disbrows brother, as one of the council, the same sallary.
Mr. Smith a Judge in Scotland 600 l. per annum.
Mr Swinton, the like place and sallary. Judge Lawrence the like
Sir Iames Mackdowell, one of the commissioners at Leeth, about 300 l. per annum.
Collonel Henry Markham, one of the commissioners for letting lands in Ireland 300 l per annum.
Sir Iohn VVeimes Tenant to the State of the Salt-pans neer Leeth, and hath a good advantage thereby.

div.head: Others serving for England Sitting in the House, that have Civil employments and Sallaries from the State.

list.item: Sir William Roberts, as one of the Committee for preservation of Excise and Customes 300 l. per annum, as Comptroller of the Exchequer, 600 l in all 900 l. per annum, he is a commissioner at the Wine Office, and one of the committee of the Army.
Dennis Bond, as Comptroller of the receipts of the Exchequer 500 l. per annum.

Captain Stone, as Teller in the Exchequer, 500 l. per annum, and great fees beside; as Receiver general of the Taxes 300, as Comptroller of the Excise and Customs 400 l. in all 1200 l. per annum, he is a commissioner at the Wine Office, and one of the committee of the Army besides.
Gervis Bennet, one of the committee of preservation of Excise and Customes, 300 l. per annum, hath also a great place in the Wine Office, and is one of the committee of the Army.
Mr. Vpton, as one of the commissioners of the Customes, supposed worth neere 800 l. per annum.
Mr. Nowell, Scrivener, partner with Thurloe in the Post Office, supposed of great advantage, and is deeply engaged with the Court Interest.
Collonel Blake Receiver of the Revenews 300 l. per annum.
Mr. Bedford, the like place and sallary
Mr. Butler the like.
Mr. Hildslie Commissioner of the Prerogative Office, 300 l. per annum, and one of the Committee of the Army.
Mr. Lucy the like places and sallarie:
Christopher Lister, one of the Tellers in the Exchequer, 500 l. per annum.

Collonel Tho. Gorges, one of the Commissioners for the New building, his advantage thereby cannot yet be known, till he and his brethren have rackt the consciences, flayed off the skings, and broken the bones of the poore people, making them swear against themselves.
Sir John Thoroughgood, one of the Trustees for disposing Augmentations towards Ministers maintenance, his sallary not well known.
Collonel James Chadwick, one of the Judges of the Peverell court at Nottingham, an old oppressive office lately revived.
Mr. Cary of Westminster Commissioner at Habberdashers hall, and Deputy Steward of VVestminster, lately deceased.
Anthony Smith, Master of an Hospitall, and a Register, supposed worth 200 pounds per annum
Robert or VVill. Fenwick Master of an Hospitall.
Mr. Thomas Mackworth farmer of the Excise in Lancashire, by speciall Order.
Master Clud one of the Committee of the Army.
Iohn St. Aubin, a sallary man, but what place he hath, I cannot learn.

div.head: The Names of the Protector (so called) his Sons, Kindred, Servants and others, who have received favours from him, and thereby engaged for his Interest.

list.item: Mr. Richard Cromwell his eldest sonne Chancellor of Oxford.
Mr. Claypole his son in law, he married his daughter, and is Master of the Horse, a place of great advantage.
Collonel Iohn Iones, married the Protectors Sister, and is governour of the Isle of Anglesie.

Captain Nicholas Maried Protectors Niece and is Governour of his Castle at Chepstow, hath one or two companies of foot beside other advantages, is also captain of a Milita Troope, and Treasurer Generall of all South VVales.
Captain Beake maryed his Neece and is Captain of his lifeguard of horse, 511l per. an.
Sr. Francis Russell, whose daughter the Protectors second son maried: as Chamberlain of Chester, formerly by the Earls of Derby supposed to be worth 500l. per an.
Edmund Giles maryed his kinswoman and is one of the masters of the Chancery in Ordinary a place of great value.

div.head: The Names of his servants Siting in the House.

list.item: Mr. Maidstone steward of his house, a place of great advantage.
Mr. Waterhouse Steward of his lands, a place of great profit.
Sr. Edward Herbert entrusted as an overseere or Baily of his Lands in VVales

div.head: The Names of Protector (so called) his Kinsmen not known to have any place as yet, that sat in the House.

list.item: Mr. Disbrow, Major General Disbrowes sonne.
Mr. Henry Cromwell.
Mr. Gobert Barrington.
Mr: Kichard Hampden.
Sr. John Trevor.
Mr. Trever his son.
Mr. Dunch, who, and the Protectors eldest son married two Sisters.
Sir Richard Everard, a good Huntsman.
Mr. Robert Williams of Wales.

p.hi: Not one of these, such men of Principles as was formerly pretended to be endeavoured after; neither indeed are the greatest part of the whole Convention any better. For which carriage of things, I am confidently perswaded, the Lord by one dispensation or other, will make the man in Power and his Councellors hereunto ashamed; for if this practise be good, the former wherein the Lord to set his Seale of Approbation, by his eminent and glorious presence with them which was contrary hereunto, was evill.

div.head: The Names of others, sitting in the House, having Engagements: from the Protector upon them.

list.item:
Aderman Pack, one of the new made Knights; for the good service he did the Protector and his Family, by his presenting the Bill for Kingship; Its said he obtained from the Protector by his Petition
or request, a discharge from an account of 16000. pounds, which he and the rest of the then commissioners were lyable to make good, for so much run out of Cash, in the time of their Commission for the Customes.
Aderman Foot, a new made Knight.
Alderman Dickinson of York, one of the new made Knights.
Antho. Nichols, one of the eleven Members, High Sheriff of Cornwall, and as is reported, lately received a reward from O. P.

Mr. Kiffin, who having received former courtesies by meanes of O. P. and his confederates, as to prohibited goods, and in other respects, is there by engaged to become his vassall, and to command a company of foot in the new militia to support his Tyrany, whilest the Saints and others are imprisond for opposing it.
Mr. Lawrence the president of the councill his son, who must do as his father.
Mr. VValer, Sr. Hadress VValers son, and is naturally engaged to uphold his fathers interest.
Mr. Keeling one of the masters of the Trinity house, and his relations at Court.

div.p: If there be any mistakes (as it is very probable there is) in the Computation of the forementioned Offices, Places, or Sallaries, you may please to understand there was not in the least a desire, or designe to doe any thing untruly thereby, to make the men or things appear worse than in truth they are; there having been all the ways and means that with Honesty, Wisdome and safety might be used to attain a right understanding in every particular; but if through any failor herein, those who are most concerned do finde themselves agrieved, knowing they are not in every punctilio dealt right with: The onely way for their own vindication and satisfaction of others, will be to give a more perfect and brief account hereof themselves, which with much ease they may doe in a little time. These things thus laid down being reported of them.

div.head: Ʋpon the foregoing Premises, it is further Proposed and Queried.
div.p: 1. Whether the Self-denying Ordinance made by the long Parliament were in force, or minded by these Gentlemen, a thing some of them so approved off, and were instrumentall in that day, to promote and carry on: May it not be desired they would better consider, and put it in practice when they meet again, seeing they have revived all Acts and Ordinances, not contrary to their model of Government, alias Instrument of Bondage to the English Nation.

2. Whether men standing under such mercenary and self-interessed Obligations, and dependencies upon a single Person, as these men do; and who like so many horse-leeches have sucked and drawn into themselves, the expected fruit of all the blood and Treasure expended in the late War, against lesse Tyranny and Oppression in the King, than they have now settled in their Protector, are fit Persons to be Legislators, Law-makers, framers of Governments, and Oaths; and Leviers of money on the People? And whether in the eye of Reason, any other can be expected from them, but that they will endeavour all they can to uphold that Interest they are hyred to serve, and whereby their own Incomes and Sallaries may be continued? For doth not the Scripture say Deut. 16.18. That a gift blindes the eyes of the wise, and perverts the words of the Righteous: And Prov. 17.8. A gift is a precious stone in the eyes of him that hath it, and whethersoever it turns it prospers. And Prov. 18.16. A mans gift maketh way for him, and brings him before great men.

3. Whether for more than one hundred years last past, it hath been heard or known, that any number of Englishmen sitting in that House, did in any wise Consent (especially in a time of Peace) as these unworthy Persons have lately done; to levy a Tax for three years together upon the People; and as if that were not enough, to order a three months Tax to be paid twice over? Together with the Excise (a Tax so much abhorr'd and created onely by the necessity of War) which with the Customs are imposed in perpetuum upon the Nation, and made an Hereditary and standing Revenue to the Crown?

4. What equality or Justice is there in that Act of Union, whereby the Scots Nation comes to be Incorporated with this Nation; so as to have equall Priviledges and Power, by their Interessed Mercenary men (as their present Trustees are) to become Lawgivers, framers of Governments and Oaths, and leviers of Taxes of the Free People of the English Nation, who were lately at so great cost and charges in reducing and bringing them under, that they might not be in a capacity to hurt or dammage them? And whether these Gentlemen sent from the aforesaid Nation, have not so far over-ruled, as to save themselves by putting the burthen on the English? having raised upon the English Nation, the three years Tax from Thirty thousand pounds per moneth, to Thirty five thousand, whereby the Scottish Nation are reduced from ten thousand pounds per moneth to six, Is the divident equall? Is not the Scottish Nation undervalued as of little; which formerly bore so high: Doth not the English loose and suffer by that Nation? And were not better to be without it? And all such Gentlemen in Parliament, that have no more sence or Recentment, what Burthens
they lay on this Nation, so they may keep their Places and Sallaries.

5ly. Whether the Judges and Commissioners of the Chancery together with such who have great places in Administring of Law to the people, and very great Advantages, and profits thereby, be not likewise to be excepted against as to Parliamentary Trust. It being most sure that they will hardly be disposed to make such laws and governments, as may diminish the splendor, or Mercinariness of their profession, seeing they are known to be men, who from time to time, have alwayes advanced their own Trade, as their present height doth witness, who to the great dishonor of the Nation, while they profess themselves the ministers of Justice, and Righteousnesse to the people, doe under that pretence, greaten, and inrich themselves, in the oppressions, and miseryes of the people.

6ly. And why is it that the despencers of the Law as well as theFree preaching the Gospell and knowledg of God is becom a crime rendering men uncapable to sit in the Parliament. Teachers of the Gospell should not be made uncapable to sit, and act in Parliament, seeing there also is an old musty act to prohibit them so to do: But it seems their envy at the free dispenceing of the Gospell on the one hand, and their gain by the Law on the other; hinders them that they cannot see or take notice of it.

7ly. The like may be queried concerning the swordmens capacity to sit whilest in pay; especially to decree, and vote, in levying of mony for three yeares together, and of other unheard off, oppressive wayes, devised and practised, for no other use, than to pay themselves their Wages and Sallaries, now they doe no work; unlesse it be to undo what they did before, and to reduce the well-affected people of this Nation, unto their first condition of slavery, to be ruled by meer will and pleasure?

div.head: Here follows a Catalogue of the Kinglings, or the names of those Persons, who Voted for a King; The truest that as yet can be gotten, with the Names of the several Counties for which they serve.

Bedford Shire.

•… ardress's Son

In All, 120. VVhereof, of the Council with the Secretary 5
Of his Kindred 12
Officers belonging to the Army and Navy in pay 20
Others receiving Sallaries and lying under other Engagements 33
In all 70.

div.p: The other Fifty are Scots and English men of slight, low, and inconsiderable Principles, and will turn any way their Master will have them.

It is reported that severall of these Persons, because their Protector judged it not safe for him at that time, to accept of their unworthy offer, being either really, or seemingly dissatisfied, went away, and would not give their vote for this new Government, now pretended to be setled; called the Humble Petition and Advice: Which as is commonly spoken, was carried but by three voyces, Fifty three against Fifty: And is also against the desire and approbation of the good people of the Nation. The Names of which Fifty three persons should also have followed in the next place, could a true Catalogue thereof been obtayned.

Nor are they hereby excused, who gave their Vote for one or the other, but seem to be dissatisfied with present proceedings, because by their sitting in the House, they pretend as Representors of the people (for whom they serve) to preserve their Rights and Freedomes, free from the Violence, Tyranny and Oppression of all Arbitrary powers whatsoever. Yet notwithstanding, as by suffering their fellow Members to be kept from them, and judged without doores. Sitting and Adjourning at the Protectors pleasure, as if they were his Servants; with many other unworthy things, which already have been, and further might be mentioned: So when they were endeavoured to be violated by the Kinglings. And being now really Trampled upon, and given away, by the above mentioned Fifty three persons. (who like so many Slaves or Vassals with Ropes about their necks, came bowing and beseeching him to take the sole Government of the 3. Nations upon him; and to choose his Successors) They do not Cry out, Protest, Declare against, and withdraw from them, (which either is, or ought to be their Liberty) in the doing whereof, these unparalelled wickednesses,
(the fruit of this late Apostacy) must of necessity fall to the ground; but thorough love to their self-Interest, unbelief, and not trusting the Lord with their outward Concernments; in bearing a thorough Testimony against them, and in standing for the good of the people, they go on with them, stifling their own Consciences, and simply endeavouring to quiet and satisfie their Oppressed Brethren, by saying, he hath not the Title of King; as if all the evill, Oppression, and Arbitrariness lay in that, when as he hath the same, and no less power, than if he had the Title, and were called King: Yea, a far greater power (as was said before) than what cost so much Blood and Treasure to oppose in the late King. Surely these slight pretences will not sufficiently excuse them in the day of their Account for thus doing.

div.head: Thus farre the Description and Narrative; A few general Queries are further Proposed for a close to the whole. And it is humbly offered to the consideration of all ingenuous People, and queried, whether the aforementioned 'persons who seem to dissent from the present proceedings, and their brethren the Kinglings, together with the fifty three new government men, who also in time may be more publick, fall not under some of these following Characters, such as know them may judge.
div.p:
FIrst, Whether they are not those who worship the rising Sun—. Or, such as have advanced great estates by the Publick, and may be in fear of being called to an account— Or such as are under hopes and expectations to raise themselves by the present Interest — Or, as are lovers of popularity, and to be in high places— Or, as are of a low and timerous spirit, not approving their
hearts to God, or redeemed from men, and so are fearfull to give offence by their discenting— Or, such as had some designe to drive either for themselves, Relations, or theA gentleman of this juncto swore he would go help settle the Church, that in matters of Religion scarce knows the right hand from the left. Clergy— Or at best, were such as thought that by their continuance there, they might so ballance proceedings, as to prevent the running of things into that extremity, as otherwise they would; not considering they did much more hurt in countenancing them with their presence, then they could do good by their Opposition, which was but laughed at.

2. How the People of this Nation should come to be concluded by, Take notice off, or be subject too this New Government, framed, and made by these men; seeing they never chose them to any such purpose, norNot one Petition from any County, or Town in England, or Dominions thereunto belonging. Petitioned them about any such thing; If they could assume a Liberty to alter the Government from what they found it; Why might it not have become them to have attempted rather the Reducing of it to such a Form, as might have answered the just ends and expectations of those that sent them, than such a heiglitening as this, of an Interest, formerly so much complained of? That an attempt to change the Government, should be cause sufficent to dissolve his last Parliament; and not be an offence in this? is there not cause to say, that having served the end for which they at first were chosen viz. the advance of their Protectors Interest and his providing for his designes (which neither the old Parliament; little Parliament, nor his former Parliament would do,) they are still continued, and kept as a reserve against the next opertunity to bring further slavery, and oppression upon the Nation.

3. Whether the Government by the keepers of the libertyes of England, the peoples, (who have not forfeited their Liberties) Representors, and a Councill of State was not or may not be more successfull for the good of the Nation, and a great deal less burthensome and chargable to the people then the instrument of Protectorall Government, or the present Government, of the Humble Petition and advice, though the former of which was so highly boasted off, as if it came from heaven, and as if one iota of it might not be parted with, and thatSee Protector (so called) Speech to his Parliament, after the old, & little Parliaments were dissolved. other foundations could no man lay, yet in three yeares time, its found utterly useless, destroying it self, so as that by the humble Petition And advice, the Idea and desire of Mr. Thurloe, and his Master, rather then the invention, and free proposall of his mercinary Juncto, it must by their pretended authority be changed for something that is likely to prove as uselesse, as that was, if not more.

4. Whether those gentlemen sitting in the house, who were chosen by the Instrument of Protectorall Government. Which they have now cast out, and introduced their new Government of the Humble Petition and advice in the roome thereof, were not in all reason to have ceased, and gone out, with the Government that chose them, rather then without the good peoples consent, and a new choyse (by this new device of adjournment) continued themselves as Lords over the nation, in this their new erected Government.

5. Whether the good old cause formerly contended and bled for, and which cost so much Treasure in the hands of other instruments, in the long, and little Parliament, be not in a very great degree and measure (if not altogether) changed and put into the hands of such, as sometimes were accounted either Neuters, or Malignants, or not so fitt for so great a Trust.

6. Whether the Lawyers, or Gentlemen of the long Robe, having gained their Protector, over to their Interest and Party (as was learnedly, & wittingly intimated, by the Speaker, at the late Inauguration, when he had divested him of his sword, and put on the Kings Robe, (That now he might speak without offence, That his Highnesse was become a Gown-man) are not in a fairer and more likely way, and capacity, to hang up the Souldiers Belts and Swords in Westminster Hall by the Scottish Colours, than the Souldiers are, to hang up the Lawyers Gowns there? As they have oft times threatned they would: Alas poor England, is not the Law, and the administring of it, as corrupt, dilatory, burthensome, and vexatious as ever? doth the striving of these two great Interests produce any good to thee? (which the souldiers once so highly pretended too) or rather is there not hereby an increase of thy pressures and burthens.

7. Whether the proceedings in the late Convention, particularly the Votes for another House, a standing Army, a perpetual Tax for Customs, to be let to Farm, the hot attempts to build again the cursed ruins of Kingship: Also resolutions to bring in publique profession of Faith, and to tye up the publique maintenance to conformity thereunto, with the endeavours that were used to have imposed a Catechisme upon us, do not clearly shew what a spirit is raised up again? And whether dos not the tendency of these transactions (according to humane probability, threaten aSee Provision for Tender Constiences in Humble Petition and Advice, Article 11. See their Act for Chatechising, and that for the Lords Day. See Bacon and Tates Ordinance against Blasphemy, now seemed to be revived by them. Rendivation of Civill and Ecclesiasticall Tyranny; against which a most solemne and signal Testimony hath been born among us by the spirit of God in his People, the blood of the Saints, and the dreadfull effects of providence.

8. VVhether the great and high concernments, formerly the travel, the hopes and aimes, of many among us, were at all upon the hearts of those in Power, or their late Assembly, to wit, a farther Reformation of things, in the regulation of Law, the dessolation of oppressive Courts, and Committees, the abrogation of Tythes, and supernumerary Offices, the removall of all unnecessary burthens, and publick grievances; with all such laws, customs, and proceedings, as were calculated for the interest of meer will and power of Antichristian and arbitrary greatness? But on the contrary hath not the result of late proceedings been such, as hath already (in part) healed the wound that these had received, and holds out a cleer intendment to restore them again to their former power, splendor, and exaltation, to the making void as much as in them lyes, the deare effect of all the Blood, Prayers, Appeals, and glorious deliverances, which have been laid out upon that acccount?

9. Whether the hard proceedings against James Nailer, in his usage and punishment (although his principle be not hereby owned) doth not in a great measure, very neerly concern many godly, sober and peaceable People in the three Nations? Have they any good assurance, they may not hereafter be dealt withall after the like manner? And whether the several Professions among us, that by the National Faith shall be concluded unorthodoxe, may not from these beginnings, and other foundations already laid, expect to receive the like entertainment, at the hands of this Generation; as the godly and faithfull followers of Christ have at the hand of the worldly Powers, and National Church in times past.

10. VVhether the Oath Ex Officio used by the Bishops in their Court of High Commission, judging the opinions, and racking the Consciences of good people formerly? be not like to come into use again? seeing swearing begins to grow so much into request, and to be so common, nor enely at Court among great men, but also in their Parliaments, appointing Commissioners (together with the Excise and Customs) to let it to farm; for do they not give power (as appears in their Act for New Buildings) to cause men to swear, who sometimes its to be feared forswear themselves? whether the land hath not formerly mourned, because of Oaths? And is it not by this means likely to do so again?

11. VVhether the spirit of the Star Chamber and Council Board, did not also rise up, and act vigorously in the house, putting them upon the project of punishing persons for building new Houses, for new families, which the Lord hath been pleased to multiply? As if his blessing of increasing the people, in, and neer London, were a judgement or curse? and the increasing of dwellings for them, a Crime to be punished by aAll Houses without the walls of the Citty for ten miles distance round, that from 37 years past to the 29. Septem. 1657. have been built upon new foundations, are by the late act to pay a full years rent to the Protector, as they may be let at a rack Rent; In execution whereof so much oppression hath been exercised already, as would take up too much room to declare it. Mulct or Fine: And if the Lord shall be pleased to withhold the Sword and Pestilence, for seven years to come, as he hath done, the last seven or ten years past, and continue the like increase of new Families, must not the foresaid families either supplant the old, or go build new Houses at Iamaca? Such being the present case already, that a house is hardly to be gotten for a family to live in? which things being considered,
might it not be desired; that those Gentlemen of the long Robe, and the great Swordmen their brethren, who have had such a fellow feeling of the conditions and estates of the poor Tradesmen and Artificers, as to impose this burthen upon them, would lend them their Inns of Court and Chancery, VVhitehall, St. Iameses, and other great houses, before the poore new families should lie out of doores, or have no houses to dwell in.

12. VVhether extream necessity did not at first introduce that so much abhorred Tax (by the English) of Excise, onely to maintaine the VVar, wherein they were then engaged, for justice and freedome, against a Negative Voice in the late King? And his claming the sole power of the malitia, as of Right belonging to him? And whether the said Tax was not intended to be continued for so long time onely, till that necessity was over and no longer, and the Nation then to be reduced to its freedome again? And if so? VVhether there be not greater reason that, that burthen should cease, and be taken off the people, than now in a time of peace (together with the Customs) be made perpetuall, and a standing Revenue to hold up and maintain those very Usurpations, and grievances, viz. a Negative Voice over the Peoples Representors in Parliament. And the sole power of the malitia in the hands and dispose of a Protector, for the extirpation whereof it was first imployed?

13. VVhether the Excise be not a Tax farre more burthensome than shipmoney in the dayes of the King? And whether the lateWhich was done by the Protector (so called) and his Council, no Parliament sitting As the King and his Couneil formerly raised Ship money. continuing of it for two or three years on the people without the least shew of Parliamentary Authority; were not an act as criminall, & obnoxious to justice, as was the levying of Shipmoney in that day? And surely had this late Convention been of English spirits, and not basely unworthy? would they not rather have broken this yoke to pieces, and freed them from that devouring oppressing Tax, than made itCan any other be expected from mercenary Souldiers, Lawyers, Sallarymen, and other Court parasites. heavier, and by a Law, bound it upon their shoulders for ever?

14. VVere not these late Acts for continuance of Excise and Customs for ever, with the delegated powers therein contained, to Swear, Fine and Imprison persons at pleasure, together with the Act of Farming out the same, with that of the New Buildings, calculated and designed on purpose against the Merchants, Tradesmen, Artificers, and the whole Citty of London, with parts adjoyning to bring them down and make them poore and low, that so like a great tame Asse subdued to the Yoke, they may be ridden at pleasure? And as fit for nothing else but to bear the burthen of the whole Nation? And whether they be well rewarded by these new law makers, for their former forwardnesse in the good old cause, in lending their money, and adventuring their lives at Glocester, Newport pannell, Aulton, and other places, for the delivering their country from those very Yokes, which are now by a law re-established, and imposed upon us?

15. VVhether these pretended Lawmakers, had not more of a selfish, than a publick spirit, in declining the way of Subsidy, and advancing their Nineteen hundred thousand pounds per Year, for the support of their New Government? by laying two thirds of the same, on the Merchants, Tradesmen and Artificers? And the other third on the Reall and Personal estates of the Nation? Have they not hereby slipt their own shoulders from under the burthen? And unworthily laid it heavy on the Industrious people? Whilest the Lawyers great places and fees, with the Sword-mens sallaries, and land purchased or got with the price of other mens blood, pay little or nothing at all?

16. VVhether the Gentlemen of this Convention, be not the very off spring of the old Courtiers, and their dependants, the late Patentees supprest and turned out of the long Parliament, at their first fitting as unworthy to come there? in that they have bought and sold the People of this Nation, by letting, and taking to Farm, their Rights and Properties? Did ever any company of men before, abuse parliamentary Authority so? As these men have done, in making an Act to let to Farm the good people of this Nation, their properties and goods, to such as will bid most? And authorising their members to become like Panders, to give entertainment to all commers, who have a mind to be Pattentees, and contract with them for power, to use the English free people as they please?

17. Whether the pretence of advancing a Revenue to the state, be a plea suffficient to warrant their oppressing, impoverishing, and enslaving the people of this Nation, to fill the States Coffer? Or rather the lusts of some great Statesmen? And whether such as buy dear, must not sell dear, and use such means to raise their money again, as will eat up the people to the very bones? VVas not Sir Abraham Daws, Sir Iohn Worsenham, Sir Nicholas Crisp, counted criminall, and Fined accordingly, for being such farmers? And whether the Gentlemen that do, and shall now adventure to Farm, may not in time, come to be subjects of like justice, as was deservedly executed upon Empson and Dudley, with their confederates, for their racking and peeling the people of this Nation formerly?

18. VVhether the raising up again the ruines of the fallen Courts and Monarchy, and the giving up the grand Interests of the people, so lately Redeemed with the price of much precious blood, out of the clutches of tyranny, into the hands of one single Person again; and this done without the advice and consent,
and against the hopes and expectations, of the most faithfull and honest part of the Nation? Be not an act highly unworthy the day that is upon us, and a fundamentall ground of dissatisfaction to all, in whom there yet remains, any sence of the late most honourable Cause, and of the experiences & appearances that attended us, while we abode uncorrupted in the faithfull, and fervent prosecution thereof?

Upon the whole, Whether these things brought forth of late, be the natural issue of those noble beginnings formerly among us; or rather the degenerate fruits of that bitter root of Apostacy, that hath sprung up since, and of late more effectually manifested it self, under the face of Authority? In an Assembly of men, made up of persons ridden by the Clergy, and acted by principles of self security, and advancement of Sons, and Kinsmen, Servants, of low spirited conquered Scots, curbed Cavaleers, and young boyes, of corrupt Lawyers and others, who prostitute their light and principles to their Diana to uphold their gain and profits. And of a declined sort of Independent, Baptised, Ranting and mercuriall divinity professors; And lastly, of mercinary Souldiers, and Sword men, who have out of fear, or covetous self-ends Apostated, and unworthily betrayed, as honorable and precious a cause as ever was on foot since the world began, of all which this Juncto was made up, and constituted.

div.head: Post-script.
div.p: This had come sooner into thy hands had not providence hinderd; what is wanting either for matter or form thou art desired (who art capable here of) to make a supply in this or some other manner more for the discovery of wickedness, and pleading for righteousnesse; and however the Apostates of this day (with their Protector) may be dispeased and rage thereat; yet considering the encouragement our Lord Protector gives thee hereunto, Isa. 9.16. VVho complains (that in aday of transgressing, lying and departing away from God, of oppression; yea when truth failed, and he that departed from evill made himself a prey, and there was no judgement) that none called for justice, nor any man pleaded for truth &c. and wondred there was no intercessor: Let not that lively active spirit, that once appeared for God, against Tyranny and wickedness in the late Kings dayes, now dye; when the same spirit and wickedness is again revived and acting, even by them who were once so instrumentall to destroy the late generation, for these very things. Your freind who hath in some measure been instrumentall herein, hath no other apprehensions in his own spirit, but that he may ere long be known, and dealt withall, as others have been formerly upon the like account; Yet the matter herein contained, being such as (if justice could take place) might not onely be signed too, pleaded for, but would certainly overcome. He is so far from being discouraged, or in the least dampted in his spirit from the publishing hereof, that he had much rather (the Lord assisting) be exposed to a state of prisonment all his dayes, yea to death it selfe, than withdraw his assistance in the least measure in this or any other thing, wherein he apprehends he may be usefull to witness against the Apostacy of this day, to revive the good old Cause, and bring in justice and righteousness to the people.
